hints.title: Voronoi Cell Size Scales as $O(N^{-1/d})$
hints.content:
116: :label: lem-voronoi-diameter-scaling
117: 
118: At QSD with $N$ walkers uniformly distributed according to $\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)$, the typical Voronoi cell diameter scales as:
119: 
120: $$
121: \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) = O(N^{-1/d})
122: $$
123: 
124: with high probability as $N \to \infty$.
125: 
126: **Precise statement**: For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists $N_0$ such that for all $N \geq N_0$:
127: 
128: $$
129: \mathbb{P}\left[ \max_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) > C N^{-1/d} \right] < \epsilon
130: $$

113: ## 2. Lemma 1: Voronoi Cell Diameter Scaling
114: 
115: :::{prf:lemma} Voronoi Cell Size Scales as $O(N^{-1/d})$
116: :label: lem-voronoi-diameter-scaling
117: 
118: At QSD with $N$ walkers uniformly distributed according to $\rho_{\text{spatial}}(x)$, the typical Voronoi cell diameter scales as:
119: 
120: $$
121: \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) = O(N^{-1/d})
122: $$
123: 
124: with high probability as $N \to \infty$.
125: 
126: **Precise statement**: For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists $N_0$ such that for all $N \geq N_0$:
127: 
128: $$
129: \mathbb{P}\left[ \max_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) > C N^{-1/d} \right] < \epsilon
130: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-21
hints.content:
134: 
135: :::{prf:proof}
136: This is a standard result from **spatial point process theory** (see Baddeley, Rubak & Turner, 2015, *Spatial Point Patterns*).
137: 
138: **Step 1: Volume of typical cell**
139: 
140: Each walker occupies approximately equal volume (by Voronoi tessellation properties):
141: 
142: $$
143: \mathbb{E}[\text{Vol}(\text{Vor}_i)] \approx \frac{\text{Vol}(\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}})}{N}
144: $$
145: 
146: For a $d$-dimensional region, volume scales as diameter to the $d$-th power:
147: 
148: $$
149: \text{Vol}(\text{Vor}_i) \sim \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i)^d
150: $$
151: 
152: **Step 2: Diameter estimate**
153: 
154: Combining:
155: 
156: $$
157: \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i)^d \sim \frac{1}{N} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) \sim N^{-1/d}
158: $$
159: 
160: **Step 3: Concentration inequality**
161: 
162: For i.i.d. samples from $\rho_{\text{spatial}}$, classical concentration results (Penrose, 2003, *Random Geometric Graphs*) show:
163: 
164: $$
165: \mathbb{P}\left[ |\text{diam}(\text{Vor}_i) - \mathbb{E}[\text{diam}]| > \delta \right] \le C e^{-c N \delta^d}
166: $$
